thread.title: Pizza on Thanksgiving? Mostly for tourists — and spies
thread.title_full: Pizza on Thanksgiving? Mostly for tourists — and spies | Toronto Star

author: Lisa Wright
title: Pizza on Thanksgiving? Mostly for tourists — and spies
text:
Photos View photos zoom
Andrew Dorich wasn’t sure what to expect when the opening weekend of the new pizza joint he manages coincided with Thanksgiving.
Though customers were lined up around the block Friday at Dundas Square to get a free pie at the much-hyped Blaze Pizza, it was tumbleweed time Sunday afternoon, save the odd tourist or student — and a curious competitor.
“We’re going to be opening nearby, so we came to check it out,” said Audra Wosik, director of franchise development in Canada for Pieology, another Southern California pizza chain with a nearly identical concept.
She and her friend ordered up a custom-built, artisanal pizza and scarfed it on the spot after it was made assembly-line style at the LeBron James-backed chain that chose Toronto for its first location outside the U.S. Just last week, the basketball superstar dropped his lucrative sponsorship deal with McDonald’s to promote and get a bigger piece of the pie at Blaze, in which he originally invested when it launched in 2012.
He and his business partners have since locked up franchise rights in Miami and Chicago to the rapidly growing chain, which aims to be the “Chipotle of pizza.” Blaze admits to borrowing heavily on the uber-successful burrito behemoth’s business model of fast casual food made-to-order in an open-concept kitchen with fresh ingredients.
It’s aimed squarely at health-conscious millenials, as research shows they are willing to spend a bit more on fast food to get better quality. Blaze has gluten-free options and calorie counts on all its signature pizzas, salads, drinks and s’more pie dessert.
Jim Mizes, chief operating officer of Pasadena-based Blaze Pizza, said in a release that the company “couldn’t ask for a better place to begin than the food-forward city of Toronto.”
The “pizzasmiths” at the counter add various choices of sauce, cheeses, meat and veggies to the dough made on site. Once you make your way to the end of the line, the thin-crust pizza is fast-fired in an open-hearth oven that fits a dozen 12-inch pizzas at a time at extreme temperatures — which is how they live up to their pledge of cooking your pie in 180 seconds.
Three tourists visiting from Brittany, France, gave their cheesy concoction the thumbs-up, as did the Pieology spies, whose Orange County-based company will introduce Toronto and Calgary to their similar gourmet pizza franchise in March as their first locations outside the U.S.
Wosik said there’s room for competition, since “Canada is about three to five years behind the U.S.” on the so-called “fast casual” food concept.
“I like how they do everything right in front of you, plus it’s healthy,” said second-year Ryerson business student Denecious Ansalem, 19.
There’s no word yet on whether James will come by the Toronto location to push the pies, but manager Dorich said he’s optimistic, since Toronto will host the NBA all-star game next February.
